title: Cash for old iPhones boosts pawnbroker H

Tue, Aug 18, 2015, 13:03 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 27 mins Cash for old iPhones boosts pawnbroker H&T By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 6 minutes ago 12.55 0.00 
Company posts 30pc rise in half-year profits on the back of its 'buyback' and loans divisions 
A surge in younger customers trading in their iPhones for cash has helped profits at H&T Group (LSE: HAT.L - news ) rise by 30pc over the past six months. 
The 100-year-old pawnbroker said that pre-tax profits grew to £2.6m in the six months to the end of June, compared to £2m last year. 
The pawnbroker, along with its rivals, has suffered from the steep drop in gold prices, which has hit the company’s jewellery trade-in business. 
• iPhone 7 price and release date: latest rumours 
However, John Nichols, H&T chief executive, said that the group’s personal loan and retail divisions were helping to offset the difficulties caused by the metal’s declines. 
Mr Nichols said that the group’s Buyback division, which allows customers to trade in electrical items in return for cash over a 28-day period, was proving popular with 18 to 24-year-olds while its Western Union (Sao Paolo: WUNI34.SA - news ) and bureau de change business had “brought a significant number of new customers to H&T”. 
The company said that its personal loan business had driven a 50pc increase in gross profits to £1.2m. H&T charges a typical 446.9pc annual interest rate for an average one-year loan. 
"There will always be demand for short-term cash from consumers," the pawnshop boss said. 
• Gold (Other OTC: GDCWF - news ) price fall: there's worse to come 
Mr Nichols said the business withdrew from the payday loan market after finding the model employed by Wonga unsustainable. 
H&T has been one of the better performers in the sector after a number of its rivals such as Money Shop and Cheque Centre shut swathes of shops on the back of the slump in gold prices. Last year Albemarle (Stuttgart: AMC.SG - news ) & Bond collapsed into administration after it was forced to melt its own gold reserves to meet financial commitments. 
Mr Nichols said that he expected there to be a further retrenchment from his high-street rivals. H&T has closed one shop during the past six months (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
